The claim is based on a report from the: 2020, which stated that the Trump administration withheld an estimated $4 million from the FDNY World Trade Center Health Program.
The U: S. Department of Treasury confirmed in a letter dated August 20, 2020, sent to U.S. Rep. Pete King, that nearly $2 million had been withheld between August 2016 and May 2020 due to debts owed by New York City to the federal government.
The Department of Treasury: s Bureau of Fiscal Service is required to "offset federal payments for the collection of delinquent debts owed to the United States." The program uses a Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) to link payees and debtors, and in this case, New York City's use of a single TIN for many subdivisions resulted in payments for one component being subject to offset for a debt by another component.
FDNY Chief Medical Officer Dr: David Prezant, who directs the affected 9/11 first responders' health program, confirmed that the amount docked from the program over the years was in the range of $4 million. He provided specific figures for the yearly deductions, with the amount increasing each year, reaching $1.447 million through late August of the current year.
